registration_responses.q19.question:
Statistical approach research aim 1: To assess whether parenting was associated with child behavior outcomes, two multiple linear regression analyses will be conducted in SPSS (version 25) within the Hayes’ PROCCESS macro (Hayes 2012, 2017), one for child externalizing behavior and one for child empathy. PROCESS estimates the coefficients of a model using OLS regression for continuous outcomes (Hayes, 2012). The negative parenting model will assess the relationship between negative parenting and child externalizing behavior, and the positive parenting model will assess the relationship between positive parenting and child empathy. To answer the primary research question of whether these associations will each be moderated by the examined endophenotypes (SCR, SCL-change, HRV-change, attentional engagement and disengagement), separate moderation analyses will be conducted for each of the five moderators using the Hayes’ PROCESS macro. Specifically, for the moderation of the negative parenting model, the endophenotypes measured in response to the negative, “for-worse”(parenting) stimuli will be implemented as moderators: SCR to the negative dynamic face expressions, SCL-changes and HRV-changes to the negative parenting film clips, attentional engagement and disengagement to the negative parenting photos. Similarly,, for the positive parenting model, the endophenotypes were measured in response to the positive, ”for-better” (parenting) stimuli and will be implemented as moderators: SCR to the positive dynamic face expressions, SCL-changes and HRV-changes to the positive parenting film clips, attentional engagement and disengagement to the positive parenting photos. Thus, five moderation analyses will be run with the endophenotype measures to negative (parenting) stimuli as moderators in the association between negative parenting and child externalizing behavior (assessing the “for-worse” end of the differential susceptibility spectrum), and five moderation analyses will be run with the endophenotype measures to positive (parenting) stimuli as moderators in the association between positive parenting and child empathy (“for-better” end of the differential susceptibility spectrum). All regression and moderation analyses will be run with sex of the child as a covariate.
We will generate 95 % bias-corrected confidence intervals using 5,000 bootstrap samples using ordinary least squares estimation (Hayes, 2012). Variables will be centered on their mean prior to analyses within the Hayes macro (Hayes, 2012; 2017). If the analyses will reveal a significant interaction, regions of significance will be generated with the Johnson-Neyman technique (see e.g., Bauer & Curran, 2005; Hayes & Matthes, 2009).
 
Statistical approach research aim 2: To investigate whether a subset of children reacted strongly to both negative and positive (parenting) stimuli (i.e., a highly reactive group), five hierarchical cluster analyses will be conducted, one for each endophenotype: SCR, SCL-change, HRV-change, attentional engagement, attentional disengagement. To identify whether there might be homogenous groups of cases that indicate a differential susceptibility pattern we will conduct five cluster analyses in total with each following features together: 1) SCR to positive faces and SCR to negative faces, 2) SCL-change to positive parenting film clip and SCL-change to negative parenting film clip, 3) HRV-change to positive parenting film clip and HRV-change to negative parenting film clip, 4) attentional engagement to positive faces and attentional engagement to negative faces, and 5) attentional disengagement to positive faces and attentional disengagement to negative faces. We will use a hierarchical cluster analysis method, specifically Ward’s linkage clustering with the squared Euclidean distances as the distancing metric (measure of similarity) (e.g. Dolnicar, 2002; Doron, Trouillet, Maneveau, Neveu, & Ninot, 2014). We examined the two-cluster solution to see if there was a relatively small cluster of children, comprising between 10-35 % of the present study’s sample, who responded strongly to both the negative and positive (parenting) cues differentiated from another cluster. To visualize the two clusters, scatterplots for measures of SCR, SCL-change, HRV-change, attentional engagement and attentional disengagement to the negative stimuli (y-axis) and positive stimuli (x-axis) were generated in heat-map style, with data points coded in two colors according to cluster-membership.

q1.value: Parents under stress: COVID-19 and parenting style in parents with high vs. low depression history

q3.value: Individuals with past depression are likely to react to stress with more negative affect, and have difficulty coping. Parenting style may also be affected by stress, especially in stress-sensitive parents. The present study wants to assess how the COVID-19, a stressor that impacts all people at this time, impacts parenting.

q4.value:
1. Parents with higher depression history will report less accepting and more controlling parenting style. This association will be moderated by (a) number of children and their ages (parents of more children with younger ages will report more rejecting and controlling parenting, especially those who have a higher history of depression) - being expected to work as usual and not getting help from parenting partner will also make the effect of past depression stronger (b) emotion regulation - use of rumination and dampening will strengthen the effect of parental depression history. (c) cognitive vulnerabilities, such as intolerance of uncertainty and self-criticism would also strengthen the effects of parental depression 
2. Parents with past depression will show more anxiety and depression in the present - this will be moderated by (a) use of rumination and dampening will strengthen the effects of depression history (b) cognitive vulnerabilities, such as intolerance of uncertainty and self-criticism would also strengthen the effects of parental depression
3. Parental current mental state (depression and anxiety) would also be associated with more rejecting and more controlling parenting

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will be asked to fill out demographic questionnaire including questions about the COVID-19 and the number of children they have etc., and then answer, in random order, the CES-D, STAI, IUS, Self-rating scale, IDD-L, and PRPBI. The study is conducted online, takes 30-35 minutes, and participants are not reimbursed. Recruitment is done through mailing lists and Facebook.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: I started recruitment yesterday (3/21/2020) but have not looked at the data at all.

question.value: I asked parents of children younger than 18 to fill out the survey. The survey is in English but I do not check their English level. I plan to recruit untill the COVID-19 no longer prevents children from going to school/day care or untill I reach wanted sample size.

q14.value: I don't have preliminary data to compute potential sample size, but I assume that if I'm interested in a moderation analyses I should have a relatively large number of participants. I expect 30-50% of my participants to have a relatively high derpession history score (IDDL>25). Considering that participants are not reimbursed and that (hopefully) the situation is time-limited, I expect this is a realistic target.

q15.value: I plan to recruit untill the COVID-19 no longer prevents children from going to school/day care or untill I reach wanted sample size.

question.value:
depression history (IDD-L), current depression (CES-D), anxiety (STAI), self-criticism (Self-rating scale), rumination (RRS), dampening, emotion-focused positive rumination, self-focused positive rumination (all three are measured using the RPA), intolerance of uncertainty (IUS).
In addition I will ask people how many children they have, how old they are, who ususally takes care of them, who takes care of the children since schools closed, how many hours a week they usually work, how much are they expected to work now, how worried they are about COVID-19.
I plan to examine the first two hypotheses using the PROCESS macro for SPSS assessing moderation analysis, third hypothis with zero-order corelations.

q20.value: I plan to mean-center all variables since this is a moderation analysis study.

q21.value: I will use the p<.05 (two-tailed) criterion to determine significance.

q22.value: I do not have any awareness check. I plan to exclude people who report they have no children younger than 18.

q23.value: I plan to include all data from completed questionnaires in each analysis.

q24.value: If I have enough participants I will examine gender differences.

attributes.title: Planning Failures Induced by Budgetary Overruns Promote Intertemporal Impulsivity
attributes.withdrawal_justification: During post-data collection analysis of this replication study, we discovered that our sample size calculation was incorrect because of a coding error, and the expected sample size was erroneously reported as 40 instead of 50. Since there is no principled way to address this problem now that the data has been collected, we are retracting the pre-registration.

attributes.title: Grace under pressure: Elements of resilience in everyday heroes and heroes every day during the COVID-19 crisis
attributes.description: Understanding what predicts wellbeing and burnout in those on the frontline.

q1.value: Grace under pressure: Elements of resilience in everyday heroes and heroes every day in the COVID-19 crisis

q3.value:
Keeping economies and societies afloat during crisis is a delicate balance between urging care and responsibility, and deterring panic. We are currently facing an unprecedented public health crisis, where human behaviour plays a critical role not only in the spread of disease, but also in response to the crisis. The current CV-19 crisis will necessitate extraordinary human resilience in order to preserve and prolong life and social order. It has been long thought that emergency service workers are a particular “type” of person (Mirhaghi, Mirhaghi, Oshio, & Sarabian, 2016; Wagner, Martin, & McFee, 2009), which draws them to that profession; however during the CV-19 crisis, similar risks are being faced by a range of professionals. Not only are emergency service workers (heroes every day) putting their lives at risk, but also other frontline staff members that work in supply chain (everyday heroes) face the same challenges. At present, we do not understand the short-term or long-term impact of working during the CV-19 crisis on frontline workers, or indeed the protective factors that may sustain these vital workers in the coming weeks and months ahead. To address this gap, we will examine both contextual and individual difference factors that are associated with wellbeing and burnout in frontline workers during the CV-19 crisis. By comparing workers from the United Kingdom and Ireland, we will assess the impact of markedly different CV-19 strategies on frontline workers. By tracking the respondents over time, we will also assess whether pandemic related factors (i.e. morbidity and mortality rate) impacts the hours these individuals work, their wellbeing, and their determination to continue in the face of adversity. Using an online survey (plus optional follow-up surveys and interviews), we will track those in frontline positions over time as the crisis develops to understand more about these heroes, and what we can do to support them to support us. 
Research Questions:
•	How do individual factors (e.g., resilient coping style, altruism) relate to levels of wellbeing and burnout in front-line workers during the COVID-19 crisis?
•	How do contextual factors (e.g., socio-political response, mortality) impact on wellbeing and burnout in frontline workers during the COVID-19 crisis?
•	What factors may protect (e.g., meaning in life, social support) frontline workers from long-term negative consequences (e.g., burnout, PTSD, poor health) resulting from CV-19 working conditions over time?

q4.value: We hypothesise that levels of meaning in life, resilient coping, altruism, and resilience will predict levels of wellbeing and burnout cross-sectionally and longitudinally in both sectors of workers being followed. We hypothesise there will be a difference between UK and Irish workers in their levels of burnout and wellbeing, and this will be associated with confidence in government strategy. Further, we hypothesise that epidemic-related factors (i.e. experience of COVID-19 diagnosis and morbidity and mortality rate) will predict changing levels of wellbeing and burnout in these workers.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
An opportunity sample of frontline workers in health and social care, and frontline workers in supply chain will be recruited through social media for online survey participation. Frontline workers in health and social care are including but not limited to: nurses, doctors, pharmacists, care home workers, and social workers. Frontline workers in supply chain are including but not limited to: supermarket staff, convenience store workers, logistics and warehouse staff, food and drink manufacture staff.

Data collection will begin when in principle acceptance has been provided and the online survey has been built. Fortnightly data collection will continue until end of May 2020. At this point surveys may be continued on a monthly basis or terminated altogether, depending on the status of the crisis. We aim to terminate the study when risk to public has been resolved. We will recruit as many participants as possible as this is an ongoing observational study.

registration_responses.q1: Grace under pressure: Elements of resilience in everyday heroes and heroes every day in the COVID-19 crisis
registration_responses.q3:
Keeping economies and societies afloat during crisis is a delicate balance between urging care and responsibility, and deterring panic. We are currently facing an unprecedented public health crisis, where human behaviour plays a critical role not only in the spread of disease, but also in response to the crisis. The current CV-19 crisis will necessitate extraordinary human resilience in order to preserve and prolong life and social order. It has been long thought that emergency service workers are a particular “type” of person (Mirhaghi, Mirhaghi, Oshio, & Sarabian, 2016; Wagner, Martin, & McFee, 2009), which draws them to that profession; however during the CV-19 crisis, similar risks are being faced by a range of professionals. Not only are emergency service workers (heroes every day) putting their lives at risk, but also other frontline staff members that work in supply chain (everyday heroes) face the same challenges. At present, we do not understand the short-term or long-term impact of working during the CV-19 crisis on frontline workers, or indeed the protective factors that may sustain these vital workers in the coming weeks and months ahead. To address this gap, we will examine both contextual and individual difference factors that are associated with wellbeing and burnout in frontline workers during the CV-19 crisis. By comparing workers from the United Kingdom and Ireland, we will assess the impact of markedly different CV-19 strategies on frontline workers. By tracking the respondents over time, we will also assess whether pandemic related factors (i.e. morbidity and mortality rate) impacts the hours these individuals work, their wellbeing, and their determination to continue in the face of adversity. Using an online survey (plus optional follow-up surveys and interviews), we will track those in frontline positions over time as the crisis develops to understand more about these heroes, and what we can do to support them to support us. 
Research Questions:
•	How do individual factors (e.g., resilient coping style, altruism) relate to levels of wellbeing and burnout in front-line workers during the COVID-19 crisis?
•	How do contextual factors (e.g., socio-political response, mortality) impact on wellbeing and burnout in frontline workers during the COVID-19 crisis?
•	What factors may protect (e.g., meaning in life, social support) frontline workers from long-term negative consequences (e.g., burnout, PTSD, poor health) resulting from CV-19 working conditions over time?
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesise that levels of meaning in life, resilient coping, altruism, and resilience will predict levels of wellbeing and burnout cross-sectionally and longitudinally in both sectors of workers being followed. We hypothesise there will be a difference between UK and Irish workers in their levels of burnout and wellbeing, and this will be associated with confidence in government strategy. Further, we hypothesise that epidemic-related factors (i.e. experience of COVID-19 diagnosis and morbidity and mortality rate) will predict changing levels of wellbeing and burnout in these workers.

attributes.title: Temporal discounting does not influence Body Mass Index
attributes.description: The prevalence of obesity has driven searches for cognitive or behavioural economic factors related to Body Mass Index (BMI). One compelling candidate is delay discounting: those who prefer smaller sooner rewards over larger but later rewards are hypothesised to have higher BMI. The findings in the literature are mixed however, with meta analyses suggesting only a very small correlation between discounting and BMI. Here we present novel empirical data (N=381) and Bayesian analyses which suggest no such relationship between discounting of either monetary or weight loss rewards and BMI. We also find evidence against our novel proposal that discounting moderates the rate of BMI gain over time. We also present our data in the context of a random effects Bayesian meta-analytical result which does suggest the presence of a small correlation overall. The strength of the correlation is so weak (2.25% shared variance) that its practical significance may be minor to non existent. However because we found decisive evidence for unaccounted for study-level variance, due to study heterogeneity, we argue that we should treat such meta-analytic correlations with extreme caution. While the relationship between discounting and health outcomes such as BMI remain theoretically appealing, our empirical and meta-analytic results suggest we should be cautious in inferring a correlational, let alone a causal, role for discounting processes in driving BMI or moderating BMI gain with age.

q1.value: Winding roads to moral subjectivism: a mouse-tracking study

q3.value:
Prior studies suggest that meta-ethical judgments - conceiving morality as objective or subjective - might engage in different cognitive processes. Philosophers, evolutionary theorists and anthropologists have described objectivism - i.e., moral externalization - as the default mechanism of meta-ethics (cf. Stanford, 2018). Subjectivist views, therefore, should require an additional effort to be formulated. This hypothesis, however, has not been empirically explored. 

In this study, we will study how meta-ethical judgments engage in differential levels of cognitive processing. Participants will be asked to categorize factual, preference and moral statements as 'objective' or 'subjective' on a computer, while their mouse trajectories will be recorded. Indices of higher engagement in cognitive processing - i.e., more deviant and erratic trajectories - will reveal participants' thought processes during the task.

Participants will be recruited to participate in a study on "Foundations of Knowledge". Upon arrival at the laboratory, participants will be asked to complete a categorization task on a computer. In each trial, participants will be asked to click on a 'start' button and a statement will appear. They need to categorize the statement as by hovering the mouse from the 'start' point to one of two boxes labeled 'objective' or 'subjective'. Unknowingly to the subjects, the statements will be factual statements ("Berlin is in Germany"), preference statements ("Prince William is cuter than Prince Harry") and moral statements ("Death penalty is wrong"). After completing the task, they will complete a brief survey with additional measures and demographics.

q4.value:
1. We expect that moral statements will be categorized as 'objective' to a greater proportion than preference statements, but not as high as factual statements.
2. We expect that factual and preference statements show lesser trajectory deviation than moral statements.
3. We expect that trials where moral statements were categorized as 'subjective' show greater trajectory deviation than moral statements categorized as 'objective'.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Participants will not be aware of the type of statements they are being asked to categorize, which will be randomly assigned.

question.value: Within subjects with 1 factor (type of statement) and 3 levels (factual, moral, preference).

q9.value: After trials of training including only factual and preference statements, participants will be presented with randomly assigned trials of any of the three types.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: College students will be recruited through ads on the Human Subjects Pool website. They will sign up in any of the available timeslots and go to a laboratory specially prepared for the study. Participants will be given academic credit upon successful participation in the study.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 110 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 150, assuming that some of the participants may produce unusable data.

q14.value:
An a priori power analysis for within-subject designs yielded a sample size
of 110 in order to obtain a medium effect size of η2 = .10 (based on Carraro, Castelli, & Negri,
2016; Rheem et al., 2018), with type I and type II errors likelihood at .05 (α = .05, 1-β = .95)

question.value: There is no variable manipulation.

Independent Variable
Objectivity: the number of times each trial is categorized as ‘objective’ over
the total number of trials will be recorded to obtain an objectivity proportion for both each trial and categories.
Outcome variables (trial level)
Trajectory complexity -  x-flips: Based on the spatial data, an index of complexity of the trajectory can be calculated. The x-flip variable accounts for how many times a participant crossed the x-axis midpoint, which suggests a greater decisional effort to pick one of the
categories

Reaction times (RT). The time length between the participant clicking on the ‘Start’
button and selecting the category will be recorded. After data collection, RTs will be re-scaled
and normalized by trials across participants, in order to account for inter-individual divergences (Freeman & Ambady, 2010)

Covariates:
- Yilmaz meta-ethics scale (Yilmaz & Bahçekapili, 2015)
- Ten-Item Personality Inventory (Gosling, Rentfrow, & Swann, 2003)
- Demographics

Outcome computed indices (trial-level):
Mouse-tracking design allows extracting multiple aggregated indices of trajectory deviation: maximum deviation (MD) and area under the curve (AUC). These variables of interest indicate the degree to which participants’ actual hand trajectories differ from an ideal trajectory – i.e., a straight line from the ‘Start’ button to the category selected. MD indicates the distance between the farthest point of the actual trajectory in relation to the ideal in a given trial. Furthermore, AUC computes the two-dimensional space created by the difference between ideal and actual trajectories (Freeman & Ambady, 2010).

After data structuring, cleaning and standardizing, we will compare the differences between the three types of statements (factual, preference, moral) within subjects. Additionally, we will compare the difference between moral statements categorized as 'objective' and 'subjective'. Mouse-tracking design allows extracting multiple indicators from the shape of the trajectories. We will look at four outcomes that may capture in different degrees our dependent variable: Reaction Time, Maximum Deviation, Area under the Curve and x-flips (see below).

We will conduct linear mixed models for each outcome, using type of statement as fixed effect, and stimuli and subjects as random effects -- assuming that individuals may have different baseline trajectory shapes that vary accross stimuli, and that stimuli within types may have consistent variance.

q20.value: As usual in mouse-tracking studies, data from trials will be standardized by dividing the whole trajectory into 100 location data points. This transformation allows computing maximum deviation and area under the curve. Additionally, a measure of velocity will be estimated for exploratory purposes.

q21.value: We will use two-tailed tests at p < .05 for the linear mixed models.

q22.value: Trials that show an unusual count of x-flips - i.e., how much the mouse hovered over the horizontal mid-point of the screen - will be excluded. A priori, we set the x-flip cutoff value at 10, yet this number will be evaluated with the actual data.

q24.value: We will explore the potential interaction of the expected effects with individual differences, particularly ideology, religiosity and personality traits. Also, we will explore the potential effects of the independent variables in the velocity outcome

q25.value: This project is starting during the COVID-19 pandemic crisis, which may challenge the availability of on-site participants. We consider to eventually switch to an online version of the study.

Additionally, we will compare the difference between moral statements categorized as 'objective' and 'subjective'. Mouse-tracking design allows extracting multiple indicators from the shape of the trajectories. We will look at four outcomes that may capture in different degrees our dependent variable: Reaction Time, Maximum Deviation, Area under the Curve and x-flips (see below).

We will conduct linear mixed models for each outcome, using type of statement as fixed effect, and stimuli and subjects as random effects -- assuming that individuals may have different baseline trajectory shapes that vary accross stimuli, and that stimuli within types may have consistent variance.

attributes.title: Causality and continuity close the gaps in event representations
attributes.description: This project explored what cues are necessary to make people "fill in" the causal interaction in an event. We find evidence that cues to spatiotemporal continuity, rather than specific event schema, drive this filling-in effect.

attributes.title: Demographic Science COVID-19
attributes.description: Demographic science aids in understanding the spread and fatality rates of COVID-19

summary.value: Governments around the world must rapidly mobilize and make difficult policy decisions to mitigate the COVID-19 pandemic. Because deaths have been concentrated at older ages, we highlight the important role of demography, particularly how the age structure of a population may help explain differences in fatality rates across countries and how transmission unfolds. We examine the role of age structure in deaths thus far in Italy and South Korea and illustrate how the pandemic could unfold in populations with similar population sizes but different age structures, showing a dramatically higher burden of mortality in countries with older versus younger populations. This powerful interaction of demography and current age-specific mortality for COVID-19 suggests that social distancing and other policies to slow transmission should consider both the age composition of local and national contexts as well as the social connectedness of older and younger generations. We also call for countries to provide case and fatality data disaggregated by age and sex to improve real-time targeted nowcasting.
